questions.text:
Which patients are at high risk of developing infective endocarditis (IE)?

 

Statements:

  1. Patients with previous IE
  2. Patients with surgically implanted prosthetic valves
  3. Patients with septal closure devices 10 months after implantation
  4. Patients with bicuspid aortic valve

A 60 year old man who is a know COPD presented with breathlessness and fever for the last 2 days. Look at the ECG and identify the correct statements regarding it?

 

 

  1. Two distinct P-wave morphologies are characteristic
  2. The first step in treatment is to address the primary cause
  3. The heart rate of MAT is usually between 80–100/min
  4. In the presence of pulmonary disease, the first-line agent is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker such as verapamil or diltiazem

A 45-year-old man with a 6-month history of diet-controlled type 2 diabetes undergoes a 2,500 kcal 4-hour mixed meal tolerance test as part of a research program. Which of the following is/are correct regarding beta cell function?

 

  1. Beta cells account for 70% of the endocrine cell mass.
  2. C-peptide is secreted with insulin in a 1:1 molar ratio.
  3. C-peptide is a by-product of proinsulin proteolysis.
  4. Initial phase of insulin secretion is affected early in diabetes.

choices.text: The risk of squamous cell carcinoma is increased by 60-fold
Melanoma is the most common skin cancer in these patients
Kaposi’s sarcoma is less common than in the general population
Use of sunscreens can be dangerous in this population

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for a regular follow-up. He underwent a kidney transplant six years ago and has had no opportunistic infections or episodes of rejection since then. He is aware of his increased risk of skin cancer and wants to know which type of skin cancer he is most likely to develop. Which of the following statements regarding cancers in this patient is true?
questions.solution: Ans. A) The risk of squamous cell carcinoma is increased by 60-fold

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a severe headache. He is afebrile. Blood pressure: 192/105 mmHg.  Cardiac and lung examinations are normal, and the neurological examination is non-focal. Urine drug screen is positive for cocaine. A CT head is normal. He is treated with hydralazine and counselled to avoid cocaine and other illicit drugs. A week later, he returns with rash and joint pain. Vital signs are now normal, with no joint abnormalities, but palpable purpura is observed along both ankles. A rotating medical student inquires about the possibility of drug-induced vasculitis. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is true?

 

  1. It is a common entity in practice.
  2. Around 10% of affected patients will experience a chronic course with recurrent symptoms.
  3. It may be caused by hydralazine but not cocaine.
  4. Kidney involvement is common.

A 35-year-old woman presents with 3 days of fever, cough, and worsening dyspnea. She has immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) treated with oral prednisolone (poor response) and subsequently four cycles of rituximab with good hematologic response. Vitals: T 39°C, HR 100 bpm, BP 122/80 mmHg, RR 28/min, SpO₂ 92% on room air. Exam shows right basal crackles. Labs: WBC 6.6×10⁹/L (neutrophils 4.5), platelets 150×10⁹/L, CRP 88 mg/L, Na 138 mmol/L, K 3.8 mmol/L, urea 4.2 mmol/L, total protein 5.1 g/dL with albumin 3.8 g/dL, AST 55 IU/L. Chest X-ray: right lower-lobe consolidation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her presentation?

choices.text: Give three successive shocks without interruption
Hold further shocks and resume CPR with warming measure to achieve temp 30
Resume CPR and continue defibrillator shocks after 2-minute cycles until reverting to sinus rhythm
Resume CPR and give epinephrine only every 3–5 minutes

questions.text: A 56-year-old female was found unconscious at her house in Ladakh and brought in by ambulance in an unconscious state. On arrival, she was drowsy with a blood pressure of 80/50, a pulse rate of 54 BPM and a temperature of 25°C. She had a background history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, stroke, ischaemic heart disease and hypothyroidism. Whilst moving her to the resuscitation room, she became unresponsive and without a pulse. Her ECG showed ventricular fibrillation (VF). CPR was started, and a defibrillator shock was given three times after every 2-minute cycle, along with adrenaline every 3 minutes. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Hold further shocks and resume CPR with warming measure to achieve temp 30

choices.text: CT angiography is the first-line investigation for all patients with suspected stroke
CT performed within 6 hours of symptom onset has high sensitivity and specificity for acute stroke
Loss of volume and hypoattenuation are features of early acute stroke on CT
The presence of restricted diffusion on MRI is highly suggestive of ischaemic stroke rather than stroke mimic

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with a one-hour history of weakness of the left face and arm. The consulting physician suspects a stroke, and imaging is requested. Which of the following are the features of acute stroke on neuroimaging?
questions.solution: Ans. D) The presence of restricted diffusion on MRI is highly suggestive of ischaemic stroke rather than stroke mimic

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (Pm-Scl positive) and limited NSIP pattern interstitial lung disease (ILD) is reviewed in the clinic. She reports several months of increasing lethargy, weakness, and dyspnoea on exertion.

On examination:

  • Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air
  • No pedal oedema
  • Scant bilateral basal inspiratory crackles

Current medications: Losartan, omeprazole, Vitamin D, and prednisolone 5 mg (tapering dose)

Pulmonary Function Tests:

 

 

Based on these findings, what is the most likely cause of her worsening breathlessness?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Thoracic wall muscle involvement

questions.text:
A 26-year-old male is evaluated for lethargy, somnolence, and jaundice. Past medical history is significant for depression, but he currently takes no medication and denies any drug or alcohol use. He is afebrile with normal vital signs. Examination shows tremor and ataxia but no hepatomegaly or ascites. 

 

Investigations are shown below -

 

 

Which of the following is the best choice for treatment?

A 59-year-old man with acute alcoholic hepatitis is febrile (101.8°F) and hypotensive (99/66 mmHg) with tachycardia (105/min). He is jaundiced with moderate ascites and spider angiomas. Labs: AST 240 U/L, ALT 100 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 160 U/L, total bilirubin 22 mg/dL, PT 24 s (control 13.5s), INR 3, creatinine 1.5 mg/dL. Gram stain of pending blood cultures shows gram-negative rods. He takes propranolol. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and fluids have been started. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
A patient is treated for Helicobacter pylori infection. Which of the following tests is most clinically useful for confirmation of cure?

choices.text: Mucosal ischemia due to low cardiac output
Direct mucosal injury from anticoagulation therapy
Portal hypertension leading to mucosal congestion

questions.text: A 43-year-old man with severe non-ischemic cardiomyopathy recently underwent left ventricular assist device (LVAD) placement. He now presents with fatigue and intermittent melena, and laboratory studies confirm iron-deficiency anemia. Capsule endoscopy shows the following finding.  What is the most likely reason for this lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Acquired von Willebrand disease

choices.text: Nutritional support and enteral feeding should be commenced immediately

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman was admitted with right upper quadrant pain and acute biliary pancreatitis. On admission: T 99.8°F, HR 90/min, SpO₂ 96% (RA). Labs: lipase 4300 U/L, ALT 230 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 240 U/L, WBC 15,000/µL, hematocrit 32%, BUN 19 mg/dL. Ultrasound shows sludge and a 6-mm stone in the common bile duct (CBD). Which of the following is true?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Next step should be ERCP

choices.text: Excessive alcohol consumption accounts for <30% of cases of chronic pancreatitis in industrialized countries
The risk of alcoholic pancreatitis is independent of the amount consumed
High-fat, high-protein diets reduce the risk of chronic pancreatic injury from alcohol
Only 5-10% of individuals with high levels of alcohol use develop chronic pancreatitis

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a long history of alcohol abuse presents with epigastric pain and steatorrhea. Laboratory findings and imaging confirm chronic pancreatitis. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Only 5-10% of individuals with high levels of alcohol use develop chronic pancreatitis

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with no prior bleeding history presents with hematuria, purpura, and a retroperitoneal hematoma. Labs: Hct 29% (prior 40%), PT 11 s (normal), PTT 47.8 s (elevated), fibrinogen 350 mg/dL, platelets 300×10³/µL. Incubated mixing study: PTT corrects to 34.6 s immediately, then prolongs to 45.8 s at 1 hour and 76.6 s at 2 hours. What is the most likely conclusion?

choices.text: Magnesium sulfate IV 1.2 g over 20 min with sodium bicarbonate aiming for pH 7.35–7.45
Phenytoin infusion with sodium bicarbonate 8.4% IV 50–100 mL aiming for pH 7.35–7.45
Sodium bicarbonate 8.4% IV 50–100 mL aiming for pH 7.35–7.45
Sodium bicarbonate 8.4% IV 50–100 mL aiming for pH 7.5–7.55

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents 3 hours after an intentional amitriptyline overdose (40 × 50 mg). She is drowsy (GCS 13/15) with dilated pupils (8 mm). Vitals: BP 88/60 mm Hg, HR 130 bpm, RR 21/min, Temp 37.5°C, SpO₂ 97% (room air). She is flushed with dry mouth, increased muscle rigidity, myoclonic jerks, and has 2–3 min tonic–clonic seizures during assessment. She received IV fluids (0.9% NaCl) and IV lorazepam 4 mg. ECG obtained and is shown.

 

 

Arterial blood gas:

 

 

How should she be managed next, based on the above findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Sodium bicarbonate 8.4% IV 50–100 mL aiming for pH 7.5–7.55

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis presents with joint pain, dyspnoea on exertion, Raynaud phenomenon, heartburn, diffuse skin thickening, and 15 kg weight loss over 2 years.
On examination, she has pitted finger scars, basal crackles, and a loud P₂.

Key investigations:

  • ANA: Nucleolar pattern, Anti–Scl-70 positive
  • HRCT chest: NSIP pattern ILD
  • Echocardiogram: Severe pulmonary arterial hypertension with mild right ventricular dysfunction

Which treatment option is not recommended?

A 64-year-old man with severe COVID-19 pneumonia is admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. He is on mechanical ventilation and receiving broad supportive care. His inflammatory markers are markedly elevated (CRP 186 mg/L, ferritin 980 ng/mL, D-dimer 2.5 mg/L). Which of the following treatments is not recommended in this clinical setting?

A 27-year-old woman from Chennai with well-controlled rheumatoid arthritis. presents with malar rash and left-sided pleuritic chest pain. She has been on adalimumab monotherapy for 6 months and had completed 6 months of isoniazid prophylaxis earlier. She has also been taking doxycycline for acne for the past 1 year.

 

Investigations:

 

 

Which blood test will confirm the diagnosis?

A 68-year-old male with atrial fibrillation on chronic warfarin therapy for stroke prevention is scheduled for elective hip replacement surgery. How many days prior to the surgery should the warfarin be stopped?
A 30-year-old primigravida is scheduled for elective cholecystectomy. Which ASA category does she belong to?
A patient scheduled for elective hip surgery is taking aspirin, enalapril, multivitamin, and metoprolol. The surgery is planned in 5 days. What is the appropriate perioperative management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Stop enalapril and aspirin

choices.text: 4 hours for solids in adults
2 hours for liquids in adults
2 hours for breast milk in infants
4 hours for solids in infants

questions.text: What is the appropriate preoperative fasting recommendation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 2 hours for liquids in adults

questions.text: When assessing a patient before anesthesia, the oral cavity image is as below What does this indicate?
Which is the gold standard method to confirm correct endotracheal tube placement?
A 75-year-old man is brought to the casualty unconscious and with unrecordable BP. CPR is started. The ECG shows asystole. What is the shock energy to be delivered via the defibrillator?
questions.solution: Ans. D) None of the above

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypertensive patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He is on tablet telmisartan and tablet amlodipine. His BP in pre-operative area is 160/90 mm Hg. Which of these agents would not be preferred for induction of anaesthesia?
A 47-year-old presents with adrenal carcinoma and hypercortisolemia. Which is the IV induction agent that suppresses adrenal function?

A 35-year-old male is posted for lower limb debridement surgery under femoral and sciatic block. The drug used for blockade is 2% lignocaine with adrenaline. Addition of adrenaline to local anesthetic causes?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Decreased Absorption of LA

choices.text: Proceed with clipping and dividing the structures as visualised

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoing elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstones is in the operating room. During surgery, the surgeon encounters unclear anatomy due to severe inflammation at Calot’s triangle. All of these are bailout procedures to ensure patient safety, except?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Proceed with clipping and dividing the structures as visualised

choices.text: Carbuncle, Incision and drainage under local anaesthesia

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with a painful, swollen lesion on the posterior aspect of his neck and shoulder. The lesion has multiple pustular openings discharging pus. What is the diagnosis and management?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Carbuncle, debridement and antibiotics

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with metastatic breast carcinoma is started on chemotherapy. After two cycles, a follow-up CT scan shows a 35% reduction in the sum of diameters of target lesions. According to RECIST (Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumours), how is this response categorised?

choices.text: Total parenteral nutrition via peripheral vein
Total parenteral nutrition via central vein

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with gastric outlet obstruction after corrosive ingestion is unable to tolerate oral feeding. Nutritional support is considered essential before surgery. What is the most appropriate route of feeding for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Feeding jejunostomy by Witzel technique

questions.text: During a hepaticojejunostomy, the surgeon selects a monofilament absorbable suture for bile duct anastomosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate suture material?

A 25-year-old woman presents with intermittent abdominal pain and a vague, soft, mobile mass in the periumbilical region that moves freely in a direction perpendicular to the mesenteric root. Ultrasound shows a unilocular cystic lesion between the layers of the mesentery. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman develops mild bile leakage following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Her abdominal drain shows bilious fluid, but she remains stable. Imaging confirms a leak from a small duct in the gallbladder bed. According to the Strasberg classification, this corresponds to which type?

A 70-year-old bedridden patient develops an ulcer over the sacral area with full-thickness skin loss and exposure of subcutaneous fat but no bone or muscle visible. How should this lesion be staged according to the NPUAP classification?

A 32-year-old male presents after a road traffic accident with dyspnea and decreased breath sounds on the left side. Chest X-ray shows bowel loops in the left hemithorax with mediastinal shift to the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Diaphragmatic rupture with herniation

choices.text: Allergies, Medications, Past medical history, Last meal, Events leading to injury
Allergies, Mechanism, Pulse, Level of consciousness, Exposure
Allergies, Medications, Pain level, Location, Examination

questions.text: During trauma assessment, a patient is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed crash. The primary survey (ABCDE) is completed, and the team proceeds with the secondary survey. What does the acronym AMPLE stand for during history-taking?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Allergies, Medications, Past medical history, Last meal, Events leading to injury

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with episodes of sweating, confusion, and tremors relieved by eating. Her fasting plasma glucose is 42 mg/dL, and serum insulin is elevated. CT abdomen shows a 1.2 cm lesion in the pancreatic tail. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Enucleation of the lesion

choices.text: PCNL is preferred for staghorn calculi and stones >2 cm
Bleeding is a known complication and may require angioembolization
PCNL can be performed in prone or supine position

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) are true, except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) PCNL is safe in pregnancy

choices.text: Seton is used only in low fistulas
Seton always cures the fistula completely
Seton helps drain the infection and protects the sphincter
Seton is made up of cyanoacrylate glue

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with persistent discharge near the anal verge following a previous perianal abscess. Proctoscopy shows an internal opening at 6 o’clock and an external opening at 7 o’clock. Which of the following is true about the use of a seton in fistula-in-ano?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Seton helps drain the infection and protects the sphincter

questions.text: A 58-year-old man develops recurrent episodes of dizziness, bloating, and diarrhoea 30 minutes after meals following partial gastrectomy for peptic ulcer disease. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: After complete recovery during the same admission

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with acute mild gallstone pancreatitis. Her symptoms resolve within 3 days, and serum amylase returns to normal. What is the recommended timing for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution: Ans. B) After complete recovery during the same admission

questions.text: Identify the type of hernia in this image?
MAGPI and TIP procedures are commonly used in the surgical management of which condition?
A 60-year-old man with colorectal liver metastasis is planned for resection of liver segments V, VI, VII, and VIII. Which type of hepatectomy is this?

A 1-year-old boy presents with persistent clear fluid discharge from the umbilicus since birth. The discharge increases when he cries or strains. There is no surrounding redness or pus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following flap reconstructions is mismatched?
